title: Ryan Giggs tells Solskjaer and Manchester United to sign five players
text:
Ryan Giggs says Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s Manchester United squad still needs five new players (Picture: Getty)

Ryan Giggs says Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Manchester United need to sign five more players to bring the glory days back to Old Trafford.

The Red Devils finished sixth in the Premier League last season and, despite spending almost £150million in the summer, are faring even worse this term.

Ahead of Sunday’s trip to Newcastle, Solskjaer’s side find themselves in the bottom-half of the league and 15 points adrift of leaders Liverpool.

United spent heavily on Harry Maguire, Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Daniel James last summer but Giggs believes Solskjaer still needs ‘four of five’ new signings.

Solskjaer’s side have made a dismal start to the season (Picture: Getty)

‘I see what Ole is doing and I support that,’ Giggs told The Sun. ‘He’s brought in three players but he probably needs seven or eight.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘So he needs another four or five. But you can’t do that over one transfer window, so you have to be patient because it will be slow.

‘What he is trying to do was much needed. He needs time.’

On Sunday, Solskjaer’s struggling Manchester United face a Newcastle side second from bottom in the Premier League, having won just once this season.

And Red Devils legend Giggs added: ‘They are both at massive clubs. When you don’t win regularly at big clubs you are going to get criticised.

‘It’s a tough club, Newcastle. I knew Steve Bruce as a player and he was a leader. They are both big enough characters to turn it around.

‘Everyone needs time and a bit of luck. Every top manager has had luck along the way.

‘You need luck with injuries and the odd decision. It’s a big game for both of them at the weekend.’

The Red Devils face Newcastle on Sunday (Picture: Getty)

Solskjaer, meanwhile, has heaped praise on Manchester United’s young players ahead of the trip to St James’ Park.

‘We’re not in the 90s now so it’s a different era, a different group that we’re building,’ he said. ‘We know there are going to be ups and downs.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘But I’m ready to see these boys blossom. There’s not many clubs with our stature that play the young players that we do.

‘They’ll have a chance to come through and we’re sure that some of these will be part of a successful team.’
